# Double (basketball)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

![Globe icon.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/48px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png) |  The examples and perspective in this article **may not represent a[worldwide view](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias "Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias") of the subject**. You may [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit), discuss the issue on the [talk page](/wiki/Talk:Double_\(basketball\) "Talk:Double \(basketball\)"), or [create a new article](/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_wizard "Wikipedia:Article wizard"), as appropriate. _(April 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
In [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), a **double** is the
accumulation of a double-digit number total in one of five statistical
categories—[points](/wiki/Point_\(basketball\) "Point \(basketball\)"),
[rebounds](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound \(basketball\)"),
[assists](/wiki/Assist_\(basketball\) "Assist \(basketball\)"),
[steals](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)"), and [blocked
shots](/wiki/Block_\(basketball\) "Block \(basketball\)")—in a game. Multiple
players usually score double-digit points in any given basketball game; the
double nomenclature is usually reserved for when a player has double-digit
totals in more than one category.

A **double-double** is the accumulation of a double-digit number total in two
of the statistical five categories in a game. The most common double-double
combination is points-rebounds, followed by points-assists. Since the
[1983–84](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_NBA_season "1983–84 NBA season") season, [Tim
Duncan](/wiki/Tim_Duncan "Tim Duncan") leads the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA) in the points-rebounds combination with 840, and [John
Stockton](/wiki/John_Stockton "John Stockton") leads the points-assists
combination with 714.

A **triple-double** is the accumulation of a double-digit number total in
three of the five categories in a game. The most common way to achieve a
triple-double is through points, rebounds, and assists. [Oscar
Robertson](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson "Oscar Robertson") leads the all-time NBA
list with 181 career triple-doubles and is, with [Russell
Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook"), one of only two
players ever to average a triple-double for a season. Westbrook currently
holds the record for most triple-doubles in a season with 42.

A **quadruple-double** is the accumulation of a double-digit number total in
four of the five categories in a game. This has occurred four times in the
NBA.

A **quintuple-double** is the accumulation of a double-digit number total in
all five categories in a game. Two quintuple-doubles have been recorded at the
high school level, by [Tamika Catchings](/wiki/Tamika_Catchings "Tamika
Catchings") and Aimee Oertner, but none have occurred in a college or
professional game.[1] A similar accomplishment is the **five-by-five** , which
is the accumulation of at least five points, five rebounds, five assists, five
steals, and five blocks in a game. In the NBA, only [Hakeem
Olajuwon](/wiki/Hakeem_Olajuwon "Hakeem Olajuwon") and [Andrei
Kirilenko](/wiki/Andrei_Kirilenko "Andrei Kirilenko") have accumulated
multiple five-by-fives since the [1984–85](/wiki/1984%E2%80%9385_NBA_season
"1984–85 NBA season") season.

## Double-
double[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Double-double")]

"Double-double" redirects here. For other uses, see [Double-double
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Double-double_\(disambiguation\) "Double-double
\(disambiguation\)").

A **double-double** is defined as a performance in which a player accumulates
a double-digit number total in two of five statistical
categories—[points](/wiki/Point_\(basketball\) "Point \(basketball\)"),
[rebounds](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound \(basketball\)"),
[assists](/wiki/Assist_\(basketball\) "Assist \(basketball\)"),
[steals](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)"), and [blocked
shots](/wiki/Block_\(basketball\) "Block \(basketball\)")—in a game. The most
common double-double combination is points and rebounds, followed by points
and assists.[2] Double-doubles are fairly common in the NBA. During the
2008–09 season, 69 players who were eligible for leadership in the main
statistical categories recorded at least 10 double-doubles during the
season.[3]

Special double-doubles are rare. One such double-double is called **double
double-double** (also referred to as **20–20** or **Double-20**). It occurs
when a player accumulates 20 or more in two different statistical categories
in a game.[4][5][6] Another such double-double is called a **triple double-
double** (also referred to as **30–30**).[7] The only player in NBA history to
record a 40-40 is [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt
Chamberlain"), who achieved the feat eight times in his career. Of the five
instances, four were recorded in his rookie season, and the fifth was achieved
the following year where he recorded 78 points and 43 rebounds in a game.

Facts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Facts")]

  * **Longest continuous streak of double-doubles** : According to the [Elias Sports Bureau](/wiki/Elias_Sports_Bureau "Elias Sports Bureau"), [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt Chamberlain") holds the record with 227 consecutive double-doubles from 1964 to 1967.[10] Chamberlain also holds the second and third longest continuous streaks of double-doubles with 220 and 133.[10] This record is before the [ABA–NBA merger](/wiki/ABA%E2%80%93NBA_merger "ABA–NBA merger") in 1976. The longest streak of double-doubles since the merger was 53 games, achieved by [Kevin Love](/wiki/Kevin_Love "Kevin Love"), then of the [Minnesota Timberwolves](/wiki/Minnesota_Timberwolves "Minnesota Timberwolves").[11]

## Triple-
double[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Triple-double")]

"Triple-double" redirects here. For volleyball, see [Triple-double
(volleyball)](/wiki/Triple-double_\(volleyball\) "Triple-double
\(volleyball\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Oscar_Robertson_1960s.jpeg/220px-
Oscar_Robertson_1960s.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Oscar_Robertson_1960s.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Oscar_Robertson_1960s.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Oscar Robertson](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson "Oscar Robertson") has the most NBA
career triple doubles with 181, and is one of the two players to average a
triple double over an entire season.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Jason_Kidd_mavs_allison.jpg/220px-
Jason_Kidd_mavs_allison.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jason_Kidd_mavs_allison.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jason_Kidd_mavs_allison.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jason Kidd](/wiki/Jason_Kidd "Jason Kidd") was one of the most successful
players at accumulating triple doubles with 107.

A **triple-double** is defined as a performance in which a player accumulates
a double digit number total in three of five statistical
categories—[points](/wiki/Point_\(basketball\) "Point \(basketball\)"),
[rebounds](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound \(basketball\)"),
[assists](/wiki/Assist_\(basketball\) "Assist \(basketball\)"),
[steals](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)"), and [blocked
shots](/wiki/Block_\(basketball\) "Block \(basketball\)")—in a game. The most
common way for a player to achieve a triple-double is with points, rebounds,
and assists, though on occasion players may record 10 or more steals or
blocked shots in a game.[12] The origin of the term "triple-double" is
unclear. Some sources claim that it was coined by former Los Angeles Lakers
public relations director Bruce Jolesch in the 1980s in order to showcase
[Magic Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson")'s versatility,[13][14]
while others claim that it was coined by then [Philadelphia
76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") media relations director
[Harvey Pollack](/wiki/Harvey_Pollack "Harvey Pollack") in 1980.[15][16] The
triple-double became an officially recorded statistic during the [1979–80
season](/wiki/1979%E2%80%9380_NBA_season "1979–80 NBA season").

There has been occasional controversy surrounding triple-doubles made when a
player achieves the feat with a late rebound. Players with nine rebounds in a
game have sometimes been accused of deliberately missing a shot late in the
game in order to recover the rebound; a few have even gone so far as shooting
off their opponent's basket trying to score a triple-double. To deter this,
NBA rules allow rebounds to be nullified if the shot is determined not to be a
legitimate scoring attempt.[17]

### NBA[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: NBA")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Russell_Westbrook.jpg/220px-
Russell_Westbrook.jpg)](/wiki/File:Russell_Westbrook.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Russell_Westbrook.jpg "Enlarge")

[Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") is the only
player to have recorded a perfect triple double (no missed shots and no missed
free throws) in NBA history[18]

From the [1990–91](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_NBA_season "1990–91 NBA season") to
the [2010–11 season](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_NBA_season "2010–11 NBA season"),
the NBA averaged 34.5 triple-doubles per season, roughly 1 in every 36
games.[19]

From the [2011–12](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_NBA_season "2011–12 NBA season") to
the [2016–17 season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_NBA_season "2016–17 NBA season"),
the NBA saw a dramatic increase in the number of triple-doubles, with an
average of 57.33 triple-doubles per season, roughly 1 in every 22 games.[20]
[Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") was
responsible for 74 of the triple-doubles during that span, or 21.5% of the 344
total triple-doubles.

Since the [1983–84](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_NBA_season "1983–84 NBA season")
season, 25 triple-doubles have been recorded by players coming off the bench;
[Detlef Schrempf](/wiki/Detlef_Schrempf "Detlef Schrempf") recorded three with
the [Indiana Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana Pacers").[21][22]

Facts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Facts")]

  * **First triple-double in league history** : According to the Harvey J. Pollack NBA Statistical Yearbook, [Dolph Schayes](/wiki/Dolph_Schayes "Dolph Schayes") ([Syracuse Nationals](/wiki/Syracuse_Nationals "Syracuse Nationals")) might have logged the league's first triple-double on February 8, 1951, versus the [New York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks"). He had 18 points, 22 rebounds and 13 assists.[38]
  * **Averaging a triple-double in a single season** : [Oscar Robertson](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson "Oscar Robertson") ([Cincinnati Royals](/wiki/Cincinnati_Royals "Cincinnati Royals")) and [Russell Westbrook](/wiki/Russell_Westbrook "Russell Westbrook") ([Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder")) are the only players in NBA history to achieve this feat.[13][39] During the [1961–62 season](/wiki/1961%E2%80%9362_NBA_season "1961–62 NBA season"), Robertson averaged 30.8 points, 12.5 rebounds, and 11.4 assists per game.[13][40] Although Robertson only achieved the feat for a full season once, his cumulative stats over his first 5 seasons gave him an average of 30.3 points, 10.4 rebounds, and 10.6 assists per game.[40] Westbrook finished the [2016–17 season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_NBA_season "2016–17 NBA season") averaging 31.6 points, 10.7 rebounds, and 10.4 assists.[41]
  * **Most triple-doubles in a single season** : In 2016–17, Russell Westbrook (Oklahoma City Thunder) recorded 42 triple-doubles.[39][42]
  * **Most triple-doubles in road games in a single season** : Russell Westbrook (Oklahoma City Thunder) recorded 17 of 42 triple-doubles in away games.[43]
  * **Most 50-point triple-doubles in a single season** : Russell Westbrook (Oklahoma City Thunder) recorded three 50-point triple-doubles in the 2016–17 season. [James Harden](/wiki/James_Harden "James Harden") is the other player to record more than one 50-point triple double with two in the same season.[43] It is more than likely that [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt Chamberlain") recorded many 50-point triple-doubles during his historic [1961-62 NBA season](/wiki/1961-62_NBA_season "1961-62 NBA season"), but they remain unofficial, as [steals](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)") and [blocked shots](/wiki/Blocked_shots "Blocked shots") were not yet recorded as official statistics.[38]

  * **Most triple-doubles in NBA playoffs** : [Magic Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson") recorded 30 playoff triple-doubles over his career; [LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") is second with 19.[44]
  * **Most triple-doubles in NBA Finals** : LeBron James recorded 9 Finals triple-doubles over his career.
  * **Averaging a triple-double in an NBA Finals** : LeBron James ([Cleveland Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers")), in the [2017 Finals](/wiki/NBA_Finals_2017 "NBA Finals 2017"), averaged 33.6 points, 12.0 rebounds, and 10.0 assists per game.
  * **Youngest player** : [Lonzo Ball](/wiki/Lonzo_Ball "Lonzo Ball") ([Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers")), aged 20 years and 15 days, logged a triple-double on November 11, 2017, versus the Milwaukee Bucks. He had 19 points, 12 rebounds, and 13 assists.[45]
  * **Oldest player** : [Karl Malone](/wiki/Karl_Malone "Karl Malone") (Los Angeles Lakers), aged 40 years and 127 days—the only 40-year-old player to do so—logged a triple-double on November 28, 2003, versus the [San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs"). He had 10 points, 11 rebounds, and 10 assists.[46]
  * **Fastest triple-double** : [Nikola Jokić](/wiki/Nikola_Joki%C4%87 "Nikola Jokić") (Denver Nuggets), holds the record for the fastest triple double. On February 15, 2018, Jokić recorded the mark in 14 minutes and 33 seconds against the Milwaukee Bucks.[47] The previous fastest triple double had held for almost 63 years, as on February 20, 1955 [Jim Tucker](/wiki/Jim_Tucker_\(basketball\) "Jim Tucker \(basketball\)") (Syracuse Nationals), in his rookie year, recorded the mark in just 17 minutes, with 12 points, 10 rebounds and 12 assists in a 104-84 win over the New York Knicks.[48]
  * **Double-triple-double[49] (at least 20 of any 3 statistics)**: [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt Chamberlain") ([Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers")) is the only player to have accomplished this; in a February 2, 1968 game versus [Detroit Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons"), Chamberlain tallied 22 points, 25 rebounds, and 21 assists.[50]
  * **Most points scored in a triple-double** : James Harden (Houston Rockets) holds the record for the most points scored in a triple-double with 60 points, 10 rebounds, and 11 assists on January 30, 2018, against the Orlando Magic. The previous record was 57 points by Russell Westbrook.[51][52]
  * **Triple-double not including points** : The only such triple-double occurred on February 10, 2017, when [Draymond Green](/wiki/Draymond_Green "Draymond Green") ([Golden State Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State Warriors")) scored only 4 points, but collected 12 rebounds, 10 assists, and 10 steals against the [Memphis Grizzlies](/wiki/Memphis_Grizzlies "Memphis Grizzlies"). Green also recorded five blocked shots in the game.[53]
  * **Longest continuous streak of triple-doubles** : Wilt Chamberlain (Philadelphia 76ers) holds the record for the most consecutive triple-doubles. In 1968, from March 8 to March 20, he recorded a triple-double in nine straight games.[54] The second longest streak is seven, a record jointly held by Robertson, [Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan"), and Westbrook.[55][56][57]
  * **Triple-doubles by teammates** : Has occurred three times in the NBA. 
    * March 14, 1964, [Donnie Butcher](/wiki/Donnie_Butcher "Donnie Butcher") (Detroit Pistons) had 19 points, 15 rebounds, and 15 assists and [Ray Scott](/wiki/Ray_Scott_\(basketball\) "Ray Scott \(basketball\)") had 23 points, 20 rebounds, and 11 assists against the New York Knicks.[58]
    * January 3, 1989, Michael Jordan ([Chicago Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago Bulls")) had 41 points, 11 assists, and 10 rebounds and [Scottie Pippen](/wiki/Scottie_Pippen "Scottie Pippen") had 15 points, 12 assists, and 10 rebounds against the [Los Angeles Clippers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Clippers "Los Angeles Clippers").[59]
    * April 7, 2007, [New Jersey Nets](/wiki/New_Jersey_Nets "New Jersey Nets") [Vince Carter](/wiki/Vince_Carter "Vince Carter") had 46 points, 16 rebounds, and 10 assists and [Jason Kidd](/wiki/Jason_Kidd "Jason Kidd") had 10 points, 16 rebounds, and 18 assists against the [Washington Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards").[60]
  * **Triple-doubles by opponents** : This has occurred only 13 times since [1983–84](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_NBA_season "1983–84 NBA season"), four times involving Jason Kidd (while playing for three different teams):[38]
    * Magic Johnson and [Jeff Ruland](/wiki/Jeff_Ruland "Jeff Ruland") (Los Angeles at Washington, February 10, 1984)[61]
    * [Jason Kidd](/wiki/Jason_Kidd "Jason Kidd") and [Clyde Drexler](/wiki/Clyde_Drexler "Clyde Drexler") ([Dallas](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") at [Houston](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets"), April 11, 1995)[62]
    * Kidd and Drexler ([Phoenix](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns") at Houston, March 22, 1997)[63]
    * [Gary Payton](/wiki/Gary_Payton "Gary Payton") and [Chris Webber](/wiki/Chris_Webber "Chris Webber") ([Seattle](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics") at [Sacramento](/wiki/Sacramento_Kings "Sacramento Kings"), April 18, 2000)[64]
    * Kidd and [Jay Williams](/wiki/Jay_Williams_\(basketball\) "Jay Williams \(basketball\)") (New Jersey at Chicago, November 9, 2002)[65]
    * Kidd and [Tracy McGrady](/wiki/Tracy_McGrady "Tracy McGrady") (New Jersey at [Orlando](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic"), February 23, 2003)[66]
    * [Caron Butler](/wiki/Caron_Butler "Caron Butler") and [Baron Davis](/wiki/Baron_Davis "Baron Davis") (Washington at Golden State, November 23, 2007)[67]
    * [Victor Oladipo](/wiki/Victor_Oladipo "Victor Oladipo") and [Michael Carter-Williams](/wiki/Michael_Carter-Williams "Michael Carter-Williams") (Orlando at Philadelphia, December 3, 2013 (2 OT))[68]
      * Oladipo and Carter-Williams were both rookies when accomplishing the feat, marking the first and only time in NBA history that two rookies have recorded triple-doubles in the same game. These were the first career triple-doubles for both players. The last time that two players had recorded their first career triple-doubles in the same game was when Donnie Butcher and Ray Scott (Detroit Pistons) did it on March 14, 1964 (they were not rookies).[69]
    * Russell Westbrook and [Giannis Antetokounmpo](/wiki/Giannis_Antetokounmpo "Giannis Antetokounmpo") (Oklahoma City at [Milwaukee](/wiki/Milwaukee_Bucks "Milwaukee Bucks"), March 6, 2016)[70]
    * LeBron James and [Stephen Curry](/wiki/Stephen_Curry "Stephen Curry") (Cleveland at Golden State, June 4, 2017)
    * Giannis Antetokounmpo and [Nikola Jokić](/wiki/Nikola_Joki%C4%87 "Nikola Jokić") (Denver at Milwaukee, February 15, 2018)[71]
    * D’Angelo Russell and Kyle Lowry (Brooklyn at Toronto, March 23, 2018)
    * [Ben Simmons](/wiki/Ben_Simmons "Ben Simmons") and [LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") (Cleveland at Philadelphia, April 6, 2018)

### NCAA Division
I[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: NCAA Division I")]

  * **Most triple-doubles in a career** : 
    * Men's: [Kyle Collinsworth](/wiki/Kyle_Collinsworth "Kyle Collinsworth") ([BYU](/wiki/BYU_Cougars_men%27s_basketball "BYU Cougars men's basketball"), 2010–12, 2014–16) with 12 — six in [2014–15](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_BYU_Cougars_men%27s_basketball_team "2014–15 BYU Cougars men's basketball team") and six again as a senior in [2015–16](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_BYU_Cougars_men%27s_basketball_team "2015–16 BYU Cougars men's basketball team").[72] Prior to the triple-double being tracked as an [NCAA](/wiki/NCAA_basketball "NCAA basketball") statistic, [Oscar Robertson](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson "Oscar Robertson") ([Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati_Bearcats_men%27s_basketball "Cincinnati Bearcats men's basketball")) had 10—five in 1958–59 and five in 1959–60.[73]
    * Women's: [Sabrina Ionescu](/wiki/Sabrina_Ionescu "Sabrina Ionescu") ([Oregon](/wiki/Oregon_Ducks_women%27s_basketball "Oregon Ducks women's basketball"), 2016–present) with 10 – four in [2016–17](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Oregon_Ducks_women%27s_basketball_team "2016–17 Oregon Ducks women's basketball team") and six in [2017–18](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Oregon_Ducks_women%27s_basketball_team "2017–18 Oregon Ducks women's basketball team").[74]
  * **Consecutive triple-doubles** : In Division I men's play, David Edwards ([Texas A&M](/wiki/Texas_A%26M_Aggies_men%27s_basketball "Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball")), [Penny Hardaway](/wiki/Penny_Hardaway "Penny Hardaway") ([Memphis State](/wiki/Memphis_Tigers_men%27s_basketball "Memphis Tigers men's basketball")), Tony Lee ([Robert Morris](/wiki/Robert_Morris_Colonials_men%27s_basketball "Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball")), [Gerald Lewis](/wiki/Gerald_Lewis_\(basketball\) "Gerald Lewis \(basketball\)") ([SMU](/wiki/SMU_Mustangs_men%27s_basketball "SMU Mustangs men's basketball")), [Shaquille O’Neal](/wiki/Shaquille_O%E2%80%99Neal "Shaquille O’Neal") ([LSU](/wiki/LSU_Tigers_basketball "LSU Tigers basketball")), and [Kevin Roberson](/wiki/Kevin_Roberson_\(basketball\) "Kevin Roberson \(basketball\)") ([Vermont](/wiki/Vermont_Catamounts_men%27s_basketball "Vermont Catamounts men's basketball")) each recorded two consecutive games with a triple-double.[75]

    In women's play, Danielle Carson ([Youngstown State](/wiki/Youngstown_State_Penguins_women%27s_basketball "Youngstown State Penguins women's basketball")), Kim Rhock ([Mount St. Mary's](/wiki/Mount_St._Mary%27s_Mountaineers_women%27s_basketball "Mount St. Mary's Mountaineers women's basketball")), [Nicole Powell](/wiki/Nicole_Powell "Nicole Powell") ([Stanford](/wiki/Stanford_Cardinal_women%27s_basketball "Stanford Cardinal women's basketball")), Ashley Schrock ([Cleveland State](/wiki/Cleveland_State_Vikings_women%27s_basketball "Cleveland State Vikings women's basketball")), Claire Faucher ([Portland State](/wiki/Portland_State_Vikings_women%27s_basketball "Portland State Vikings women's basketball")), [Brittney Griner](/wiki/Brittney_Griner "Brittney Griner") ([Baylor](/wiki/Baylor_Lady_Bears_basketball "Baylor Lady Bears basketball")), Ny Hammonds ([Charlotte](/wiki/Charlotte_49ers_women%27s_basketball "Charlotte 49ers women's basketball")), and Ionescu have accomplished this feat.[76]

  * Uniquely, Danielle Carson recorded three consecutive triple-doubles in the 1985–86 season, becoming the only Division I player of either sex to do so. She began by recording 12 points, 10, rebounds, and 12 assists against [Akron](/wiki/Akron_Zips_women%27s_basketball "Akron Zips women's basketball") on November 29, 1985. The following day, she recorded 20 points, 12 rebounds, and at least 20 assists against [Kent State](/wiki/Kent_State_Golden_Flashes_women%27s_basketball "Kent State Golden Flashes women's basketball") (her exact assists total in that game is unknown). Finally, on December 2 against Cleveland State, Carson recorded 26 points, 15 rebounds, and 14 assists.[76]

  * **Most triple-doubles in a single season** : 
    * Men's: Kyle Collinsworth (BYU), with six – performed twice: in the 2014–15 season, and again in 2015–16.[72]
    * Women's: Danielle Carson (Youngstown State) and Sabrina Ionescu (Oregon), each with six — Carson in 1985–86[76] and Ionescu in 2017–18.

## Quadruple-
double[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Quadruple-double")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/David_Robinson_%28Team_USA%29.jpg/200px-
David_Robinson_%28Team_USA%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:David_Robinson_\(Team_USA\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:David_Robinson_\(Team_USA\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Center](/wiki/Center_\(basketball\) "Center \(basketball\)") [David
Robinson](/wiki/David_Robinson_\(basketball\) "David Robinson \(basketball\)")
is the most recent NBA player to accomplish the feat of a quadruple-double by
recording at least 10 points, rebounds, assists, and blocks in a game.

A **quadruple-double** is defined as a performance in which a player
accumulates a double digit number total in four of five statistical
categories—[points](/wiki/Point_\(basketball\) "Point \(basketball\)"),
[rebounds](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound \(basketball\)"),
[assists](/wiki/Assist_\(basketball\) "Assist \(basketball\)"),
[steals](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)") and [blocked
shots](/wiki/Block_\(basketball\) "Block \(basketball\)")—in a game.[86] This
feat is extremely rare:[86][87] only four players have officially recorded a
quadruple-double in [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA) history. The first American male player above the high
school level to officially record a quadruple-double was [Nate
Thurmond](/wiki/Nate_Thurmond "Nate Thurmond"), who achieved this feat in 1974
while playing for the NBA's [Chicago Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago
Bulls"). The first American female player above the high school level to
officially record a quadruple-double was [Ann Meyers](/wiki/Ann_Meyers "Ann
Meyers"), who achieved this feat in 1978 while playing for the [UCLA
Bruins](/wiki/UCLA_Bruins_women%27s_basketball "UCLA Bruins women's
basketball"), when women's college sports were under the auspices of the
[AIAW](/wiki/Association_of_Intercollegiate_Athletics_for_Women "Association
of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women").[88] The first male player in NCAA
Division I history to record a quadruple-double was [Lester
Hudson](/wiki/Lester_Hudson "Lester Hudson") in 2007.[89] The first Division I
women's player to have officially recorded a quadruple-double since the NCAA
began sponsoring women's sports in 1981–82 was Veronica Pettry of
[Loyola–Chicago](/wiki/Loyola_Ramblers_women%27s_basketball "Loyola Ramblers
women's basketball") in 1989. Only three other women have done so since, and
Shakyla Hill's quadruple-double for [Grambling
State](/wiki/Grambling_State_Tigers_and_Lady_Tigers "Grambling State Tigers
and Lady Tigers") in 2018 was the first since 1993. An earlier player, Jackie
Spencer of [Louisville](/wiki/Louisville_Cardinals_women%27s_basketball
"Louisville Cardinals women's basketball"), accomplished the feat against
[Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati_Bearcats_women%27s_basketball "Cincinnati
Bearcats women's basketball") during the 1984–85 season, but the NCAA did not
record assists and steals throughout Division I women's basketball at that
time. The [Metro Conference](/wiki/Metro_Conference "Metro Conference"), then
home to both schools, did officially record these statistics, but the NCAA did
not start doing so until 1985–86 for assists and 1987–88 for steals.[76]

### NBA[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: NBA")]

Quadruple-doubles have only been possible since the [1973–74
season](/wiki/1973%E2%80%9374_NBA_season "1973–74 NBA season"), when the NBA
started recording both blocked shots and steals. It is often speculated by
observers that other all-time greats, namely [Oscar
Robertson](/wiki/Oscar_Robertson "Oscar Robertson") (all time triple-doubles
leader with 181[90][91]), [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt
Chamberlain"), [Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell") and [Jerry
West](/wiki/Jerry_West "Jerry West") could conceivably have had quadruple-
doubles.[87] West's biography at NBA.com claims that he once recorded an
unofficial quadruple-double with 44 points, 12 rebounds, 10 assists and 10
blocks.[92] A biography of Wilt Chamberlain claims that he also recorded an
unofficial quadruple-double in Game 1 of the 1967 Eastern Division Finals
against the [Boston Celtics](/wiki/1966%E2%80%9367_Boston_Celtics_season
"1966–67 Boston Celtics season"), when he had 24 points, 32 rebounds, 13
assists and 12 blocks.[93]

> The reason why [the quadruple-double] is such a hard thing to accomplish is
> because it requires a player to be completely dominant on both ends of the
> court without being too selfish—so he can get the assists—and without
> fouling out trying to block every shot or grab every rebound. A lot of guys
> can get the points, rebounds and assists, but it's the defensive stuff that
> messes everybody up. You have to love defense to get a quadruple-double.
> There's no way around it.
>
> — Nate Thurmond, [94]

The four players listed below are the only players who have officially
recorded a quadruple-double in an NBA game. Except for Thurmond, who retired
before the award was established in 1983, all of them have won [NBA Defensive
Player of the Year](/wiki/NBA_Defensive_Player_of_the_Year_Award "NBA
Defensive Player of the Year Award") at least once.[94]

  * **b** Olajuwon was credited with 9 assists in the original box score. However, after Rockets officials reviewed the game tape and discovered what they believe was an uncredited assist in the first quarter, they revised the box score, crediting Olajuwon with 10 assists and the third quadruple-double in NBA history. NBA's director of operations, [Rod Thorn](/wiki/Rod_Thorn "Rod Thorn"), requested to review the tape. After reviewing the tape, the league disallowed Olajuwon's quadruple-double and announced that his original line—with 9 assists—is official.[111][112]

## Quintuple-
double[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Quintuple-double")]

A **quintuple-double** is defined as a performance in which a player
accumulates a double-digit number total in all five statistical
categories—points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocked shots—-in a single
game.[142] There are only two known quintuple-doubles, both done at the high-
school level. The first was recorded by [Tamika
Catchings](/wiki/Tamika_Catchings "Tamika Catchings") of [Duncanville High
School](/wiki/Duncanville_High_School "Duncanville High School")
([Duncanville, Texas](/wiki/Duncanville,_Texas "Duncanville, Texas")) with 25
points, 18 rebounds, 11 assists, 10 steals and 10 blocks in 1997.[143] The
second was by Aimee Oertner of [Northern Lehigh High
School](/wiki/Northern_Lehigh_High_School "Northern Lehigh High School")
([Slatington, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Slatington,_Pennsylvania "Slatington,
Pennsylvania")), who had 26 points, 20 rebounds, 10 assists, 10 steals, and 11
blocks on January 7, 2012.[144]

## Five-by-
five[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Five-by-five")]

A **five-by-five** is defined as a performance in which a player accumulates a
total of five in five statistical categories—points, rebounds, assists,
steals, and blocks—in a single game.[145] Statistics for steals and blocks
were not kept in the NBA until the 1973–74 season, so NBA five-by-fives were
only possible from that season onward. [Hakeem Olajuwon](/wiki/Hakeem_Olajuwon
"Hakeem Olajuwon") (six times) and [Andrei Kirilenko](/wiki/Andrei_Kirilenko
"Andrei Kirilenko") (three times) are the only players to have recorded
multiple five-by-fives (based on records since the
[1984–85](/wiki/1984%E2%80%9385_NBA_season "1984–85 NBA season") season).[145]
Both are also the only players to record five-by-sixes (at least six in all
five statistical categories).[145] Only twice has a five-by-five coincided
with a triple-double (both by Olajuwon) and only three times has a player
recorded a five-by-five without registering at least a double-double (two by
Kirilenko and one by [Marcus Camby](/wiki/Marcus_Camby "Marcus Camby")).

###
Facts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Double_\(basketball\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Facts")]

All facts based on data since [1985–86](/wiki/1985%E2%80%9386_NBA_season
"1985–86 NBA season"):

  * **Greatest five-by-fives (most of each stat)** : Hakeem Olajuwon, on March 10, 1987, became the first in NBA history to record a five-by-six (at least 6 each of all five statistics: points, rebounds, assists, blocks, steals).[163] It took nearly twenty years for the second official occurrence in NBA history. Andrei Kirilenko, on January 3, 2006, recorded a five-by-six against the Lakers. Though his numbers were not quite as impressive as Olajuwon's, Kirilenko performed the feat in regulation.
  * **Most five-by-fives in a career** : Hakeem Olajuwon leads all players with 6 career five-by-fives.[145] Andrei Kirilenko, with 3, is the only other player with more than one career five-by-five.
  * **Most five-by-fives in the same season** : Only twice has a player recorded two five-by-fives in a season. Olajuwon in the 1993–94 season, and Kirilenko in the 2003–04 season.
  * **Quickest pair of five-by-fives** : Kirilenko performed a five-by-five on December 3, 2003, and completed another just a week later, on December 10, 2003. The second quickest five-by-fives were completed by Olajuwon on November 5, 1993, and another, 55 days later, on December 30, 1993.
  * **Youngest player** : Kirilenko's first NBA five-by-five came on December 3, 2003, making him the youngest to record a five-by-five at age 22 years, 288 days.
  * **Oldest player** : Olajuwon is the oldest player to record a five-by-five. His last career five-by-five came on December 30, 1993, at which time he was 30 years, 343 days old.
